Dog treat.text: In an attempt to distract the surveillance cameras, you threw the dog treat towards the shark tank, hoping the splash would divert attention. Unfortunately, the treat barely made it past the edge, and instead of drawing the cameras' gaze, you drew the curious stares of nearby partygoers, including the suspicious guest.

Art supplies.text: In an attempt to use your art supplies, you sketch a highly detailed scene of the tank, hoping to distract Sherlock Smythe and the guests with your artistic prowess. However, your plan backfires when Smythe becomes overly fixated on the inaccuracies between your drawing and the actual scene, drawing even more attention to the tank and the critical clue slipping further into the depths, unnoticed by all but the sharks.

Screwdriver.text: Attempting to use the screwdriver to dismantle the nearby railing for materials to fashion a long reaching tool, you lose your grip. The screwdriver slips from your hand and sinks swiftly to the bottom of the shark tank, out of reach.

Digital camera.text: You used the digital camera to snap a high-resolution photo of the suspect discreetly throwing the object into the shark tank, capturing both the suspicious action and the object's trajectory. Later, you zoomed in on the photo to identify the thrown object, allowing you to retrieve it safely when Sherlock distracted everyone with his mermaid theories.

Birdseed.text: Assuming birds would flock to the birdseed and somehow retrieve the clue from the shark tank, you scatter it nearby. Unfortunately, instead of helpful avian detectives, you attract a swarm of pigeons that cause a chaotic diversion, drawing even more attention to the scene and none to the tank.

Mirror.text: Attempting to use the mirror to reflect sunlight and startle the shark away, you mistakenly caught the attention of Sherlock Smythe, who, convinced the light was a secret mermaid signal, dove into the tank, causing a commotion and ruining any chance of discreetly retrieving the clue.

Pencil.text: As you attempt to use the pencil to distract the sharks by tossing it in the tank, hoping they chase it instead of you, the sharp-toothed fish ignore the small object completely, leaving you with no plan and one less pencil.

Translation app.text: Hoping to communicate your intentions to the shark calmly, you point your translation app towards the tank, forgetting it's designed for human languages, not shark. The app translates your plea into a splashy mess of words, contributing nothing but your own bafflement.

Laptop.text: In an attempt to retrieve the clue without getting wet, you tried coaxing the nearby marine life to push the clue out of the tank with a marine animals documentary playing on your laptop. Unfortunately, the only attention you garnered was from Sherlock Smythe, who, utterly fascinated, began a loud monologue about the intelligence of fish, inadvertently alerting the suspect to your intentions.

Blanket.text: Attempting to use the blanket to discreetly fish out the clue, you accidentally draped it too close to the water's surface. A curious shark, mistaking it for a giant jellyfish, latched onto the blanket and dragged it into the depths, rendering your retrieval plan a wash.

Headphones.text: In an attempt to distract the sharks with the sound of a podcast about oceanic life, you underestimated how waterproof your headphones were. When you dangled them into the water to lure the sharks away, they shorted out immediately, leaving both the sharks and Sherlock completely unfooled.

Fishing net.text: You waited until the suspicious guest had moved away, then, using the fishing net, you carefully extended it towards the shark tank, skimming the surface where the clue had floated. With precision, you scooped it up, avoiding any disturbance that might attract the sharks or, worse, Sherlock's wandering attention.

Evidence bag.text: You skillfully waited until the suspicious guest was distracted by Sherlock's theatrics, then, using the evidence bag, you swooped in and quickly enclosed the discarded object from the edge of the shark tank without so much as disturbing the water, let alone the sharks.

Tongs.text: You waited until the suspicious guest moved away, then casually approached the shark tank with the tongs in hand. With a steady grip and precise timing, you managed to fish out the critical clue from the tank, making it look like you were just toying with the water, all while Sherlock Smythe was distracted by his mermaid theories.

Waterproof bag.text: You discreetly slipped the waterproof bag into the shark tank, waited until the suspicious item drifted into it, then carefully reeled it back using a pre-attached string, all while Sherlock Smythe was distracted by his mermaid fantasies.

Gloves.text: Using the gloves, you carefully reached into the tank, avoiding alerting the sharks by moving slowly and with purpose. You managed to grasp and retrieve the clue without arousing suspicion or endangering yourself.

Camera.text: You use the camera to take a series of photos of the suspicious guest from multiple angles, including one where the clue is visible before it's thrown into the shark tank, thus documenting the crucial evidence without needing to retrieve it physically.

Pen.text: You tried to use the pen to distract Sherlock from his mermaid theories, intending to signal someone for help with the tank. However, Sherlock, in his enthusiasm for mythical creatures, mistook your pen waving as confirmation of the mermaid's existence and began to draw even more attention to both of you.

First-aid kit.text: In an attempt to distract the party guests and pull Sherlock away from his mermaid theories, you used the first-aid kit to fake a dramatic accident. Unfortunately, your theatrical faint was too convincing, causing a real panic. In the ensuing chaos, the first-aid kit was trampled and its contents scattered, rendering it useless for any clever distraction or actual first-aid purposes thereafter.

Distraction device.text: You deftly set up the distraction device near the edge of the party, far from the shark tank, and activated it. The device emitted a series of loud, bizarre noises that perfectly mimicked the alleged calls of a mermaid, successfully pulling Sherlock Smythe and the majority of guests towards it, giving you ample cover to retrieve the discarded clue from the tank unnoticed.

Handkerchief.text: As you attempted to use the handkerchief to fish out the clue, the slippery fabric easily slid out of your grasp and fluttered down into the shark tank, instantly becoming a new plaything for its toothy inhabitants.

Candy.text: In a desperate bid to neutralize the poison, you crush the candy, hoping its sugar might somehow counteract the toxin. Unfortunately, the only result is the captain's grimace as the sugary paste only exacerbates his nausea without affecting the poison's progression.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: In an attempt to block out Sherlock Smythe's incessant, misguided theorizing so you could think clearly, you employed the noise-cancelling headphones. Unfortunately, this also dampened the subtle but crucial cries for help from a crew member who had witnessed the poisoning, leaving you without a key piece of information.

Fake mustache.text: In an ambitious attempt to divert attention and buy more time, you slapped the fake mustache on Sherlock Smythe, hoping his "disguise" would fool the crew. Unfortunately, it only made him more recognizable, as he strutted around with misplaced confidence, drawing more scrutiny and hastening your need to find an antidote.

Notebook.text: In your attempt to list the symptoms and concoct a remedy, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your chemical notations for a secret code about the poisoner's identity, excitedly snatched the notebook from your hands. He presented it to the suspects as 'irrefutable evidence,' soaking it in tea to 'reveal the hidden messages,' thus ruining your notes and any hope of creating an antidote in time.

Sticky notes.text: In your attempt to label the antidote ingredients with sticky notes, the notes' adhesive failed due to the humid sea air, causing crucial mixing instructions to become lost among the myriad of reagents.

Costume.text: Thinking a dramatic disguise might divert attention from the dire situation, you put on the captain's costume, hoping to impersonate him convincingly. Unfortunately, your performance did little more than entertain Sherlock Smythe, who, failing to understand the severity of the moment, accidentally revealed your ruse in front of the crew, frustrating your efforts to maintain order and search for an antidote.

Invisible ink pen.text: In a desperate attempt, you tried to write out the chemical formula for the antidote using the invisible ink, planning to reveal it with heat later. However, under the pressing time and no immediate source of controlled heat, the message remained unseen and useless.

Lollipop.text: You attempted to create an antidote using the lollipop's sugar as a base, hoping its simplicity might neutralize the poison. Instead, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your concoction for a treat, snatched it up and devoured it before it could be tested, leaving you back at square one.

Tape.text: You use the tape to restrict access to the contaminated area of the ship, preventing anyone else from being poisoned while you work on the antidote. The tape remains in your possession, as you only needed a portion to block off the section.

Lock pick set.text: Using the lock pick set, you deftly unlock the ship's medical cabinet, which had been accidentally sealed by Sherlock's careless fumblings earlier. Inside, you find the necessary ingredients and concoct the antidote, saving the captain and everyone on board.

Magnifying glass.text: You used the magnifying glass to closely inspect the ship's store of medicinal herbs, identifying the ones with the specific properties needed to neutralize the poison. Smythe, believing he's aiding, made grandiose gestures, while you, in reality, deciphered the antidote's recipe based on close observation of plant characteristics.

Pocket mirror.text: In a desperate attempt to use the pocket mirror to signal for help from a passing ship, you accidentally blinded the only crew member knowledgeable about poisons with the mirror's glare, hindering the antidote's concoction process even further.

Map.text: In an inspired attempt, you tried to use the map to identify local plants that could be used to concoct an antidote, but your lack of botanical knowledge meant you couldn't differentiate between healing herbs and deadly poisons on the icons, leading to a dangerously misguided effort.

Voice recorder.text: You thought to record the captain's slurred speech in hopes of deciphering a clue to the poison, but instead, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking it for a game, played the sounds loudly, alerting the real culprit to your investigation and causing further chaos without yielding any useful information.

Disguise kit.text: In a misguided attempt to blend in with the crew and secretly administer an antidote, you realize too late that a disguise kit offers no solution for concocting a remedy from scratch, leading to baffled looks from the crew as you awkwardly mill about in nautical garb with no actual plan.

Flashlight.text: By shining the flashlight across the ship's dimly lit medical bay, you revealed hidden labels on otherwise indistinguishable vials, enabling you to identify and mix the correct ingredients for the antidote.

Smartphone.text: You quickly used your smartphone to access a database of symptoms and matching antidotes, identifying the poison and concocting an antidote using the ship's medical supplies.

Binoculars.text: In an ambitious attempt to spot a hidden stash of antidote ingredients using the binoculars, you instead draw the attention of a nosy passenger. Their incessant questions about what you're spying on lead Sherlock Smythe right into a comically exaggerated story of a distant ship carrying the cure, sending you both on a wild goose chase that ends in nothing but sea spray and wasted time.

Decoy flyer.text: You tried to distract Sherlock with the decoy flyer, hoping to buy time to mix the antidote. Unfortunately, Sherlock became obsessed with the fictional event on the flyer, causing more chaos and drawing unwanted attention, hampering your efforts to gather necessary ingredients discreetly.

Dog treat.text: In a desperate attempt, you crush the dog treat, hoping its dubious ingredients might counteract the poison. Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your actions for a clue, eagerly consumes the crushed treat before you can stop him, offering no benefit to the captain's dire situation.

Art supplies.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock and hide your true intentions, you decided to create a vivid, instructional mural on the ship's deck, showing the crew how to mix various potential antidotes. Unfortunately, your plan backfired when Sherlock, eager to contribute, accidentally knocked over a bucket of paint, ruining your supplies and leaving a colorful, yet toxic, mess instead of a life-saving guide.

Screwdriver.text: In your attempt to use the screwdriver to pry open a locked medical cabinet potentially containing antidote ingredients, the tool slips and jams, rendering it useless for any further attempts and leaving the cabinet firmly locked.

Digital camera.text: In a moment of inspiration, you attempt to use the digital camera to document the arrangement and condition of the remaining items aboard for later analysis, hoping to identify the poison by process of elimination. However, your plan falters when Sherlock Smythe, attempting to "assist," inadvertently deletes all the photos believing he was enhancing them, leaving you with no visual records and no closer to identifying the poison.

Birdseed.text: In a desperate attempt to neutralize the poison coursing through the captain's veins, you grind the birdseed into a questionable powder, convinced its natural compounds will aid in concoction. Unfortunately, the only reaction it sparks is an intense allergic flare-up in both the captain and Sherlock, further complicating the medical emergency onboard.

Mirror.text: Attempting to use the mirror to identify symptoms in the captain's pupils for clues to the antidote, Sherlock, misunderstanding your intentions, snatches it to practice his "deductive glare," dropping it in the process. It shatters, removing your chance to use it in any productive capacity.

Pencil.text: In an attempt to extract graphite for a makeshift detoxifying agent, you mistakenly believed the pencil's composition could neutralize the poison; unfortunately, your basic chemistry failed you, leading to a wasted effort and a still-suffering captain.

Translation app.text: In an attempt to translate the ancient maritime tome that detailed the poison's antidote, the app consistently misidentified medical terms as culinary ones, leading you to mix a concoction more suitable for seasoning fish than curing poison.

Laptop.text: You use the laptop to access a database of medical journals, quickly identifying the poison and finding a guide to concoct an antidote using common shipboard chemicals.

Blanket.text: In a hopeful, yet misguided attempt to use the blanket to keep the captain warm, you fail to realize that warmth does nothing to counteract the poison coursing through his veins. The captain's condition worsens as precious time is squandered.

Headphones.text: In your haste to concoct an antidote, you tried to use the headphones to listen for the subtle differences in the ship's engine vibrations, hoping it might guide you to a hidden compartment with antidote ingredients. Sherlock Smythe, misunderstanding your intent, began an impromptu dance performance, tangling himself in the wires and rendering the headphones broken and useless for listening or any other purpose.

Fishing net.text: In an attempt to gather rare sea plants tangled within, hoping their properties could counteract the poison, you dredged the fishing net through the sea. Unfortunately, the only haul was a disappointing mix of seaweed, old boots, and a very annoyed crab, none of which contributed to an antidote.

Evidence bag.text: You cleverly used the evidence bag to safely collect plants and chemicals present on The Sea's Whisper proven to counteract the poison, following your own knowledge of toxicology, while Sherlock Smythe distracted the panicked guests with his unfounded theories.

Tongs.text: Using the tongs, you carefully collect venomous jellyfish found in a water tank onboard. Their toxins, when properly applied, act as a counteragent to the poison afflicting the captain. You manage this delicate operation without touching the dangerous creatures, demonstrating a lesser-known but critical application of your equipment.

Waterproof bag.text: Thinking the waterproof bag would protect the makeshift antidote ingredients from the sea's humidity, you didn't account for Sherlock Smythe's clumsy spillage of seawater inside the bag, ruining the contents.

Gloves.text: By wearing the gloves, you meticulously handled various toxic and reactive substances found in the ship's laboratory, combining them to create an effective antidote for the captain without endangering yourself through direct contact with dangerous chemicals.

Camera.text: In an overly ambitious attempt to use the camera's flash to startle a confession from the real perpetrator, you only succeeded in alerting them to your suspicions, causing chaos on deck without garnering any useful information about the poison or its antidote.

Pen.text: In a moment of misguided inspiration, you uncapped the pen, hoping to draft an antidote recipe found in your memory. Alas, the pen only managed to leave a pathetic blob of ink on your notes, far from the alchemical breakthrough needed to save the captain.

First-aid kit.text: You quickly rummaged through the first-aid kit, finding activated charcoal tablets intended for treating accidental poisoning. Knowing they could effectively bind to most poisons and prevent their absorption, you administered them to the captain, buying enough time for a full recovery.

Distraction device.text: To concoct the antidote, you needed to secure the ship's medical bay without interruption. You employed your distraction device, a high-pitched alarm, cleverly outside to draw everyone's attention away from the bay. This provided the perfect cover for you to work in peace, swiftly concocting the antidote and saving the day while Sherlock Smythe handled the "emergency" outside, bumbling about with heroic ineptitude, none the wiser to your life-saving efforts.

Handkerchief.text: In an act of sheer desperation, you attempted to filter the poison from the captain's body by using the handkerchief as a makeshift sieve. Alas, physics and biology condemned your effort to utter failure, for a fabric weave can't filter toxins at a molecular level.

Candy.text: Attempting to use the candy as a bribe, you offered it to the security officer. However, he was unamused by the pitiful offering and tightened Sherlock Smythe’s handcuffs, commenting on your lack of professionalism.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: In an attempt to disrupt the arrest by creating a silent protest, you don the noise-cancelling headphones, expecting their technology to magically silence the surroundings for everyone else. However, only you enjoy the bubble of quiet, leaving others unaffected and ensuring Sherlock's trip to the police station proceeds without interruption.

Fake mustache.text: You slip the fake mustache onto Sherlock Smythe while the security officer's back is turned, transforming him into an unrecognizable guest. The officer, doubting his earlier accusation, releases Sherlock, who you quickly guide away under the guise of escorting a distressed partygoer.

Notebook.text: In your attempt to use the notebook to piece together a logical argument for Sherlock's innocence, your explanations only further convinced the security officer of Sherlock's guilt, as he believed the notes were part of a sophisticated cover-up.

Sticky notes.text: You attempted to use the sticky notes to plaster over the security camera lenses, hoping to create a blind spot to sneak Sherlock out. However, the adhesive on the sticky notes was too weak; they fell off almost immediately, attracting even more attention to your ill-conceived rescue attempt.

Costume.text: You donned the costume of a high-profile defense attorney known for his eccentric attire, bluffing your way into the police station. With your expert impersonation, you convinced the officers that Sherlock Smythe was deep undercover on a case of national security, leading to his immediate release.

Invisible ink pen.text: You tried to write a message to the key witness with your invisible ink pen, planning to reveal it with heat later in a dramatic turn. However, the pen's ink reacted poorly to the extravagant, glossy paper at the ball, rendering the message irretrievably blurred and impossible to reveal, sabotaging your clever plan.

Lollipop.text: You tried to bribe the security officer with the lollipop to free Sherlock, but all you received was a confused glare and a firm, "This is not how the law works, buddy."

Tape.text: In a misguided attempt to create a diversion, you used the tape to fasten a glitter bomb, hoping the resultant chaos would allow for Sherlock's escape. Unfortunately, the makeshift bomb was too weak to burst, instead making a pitiful fizzling noise before security tightened their grip on both you and Sherlock.

Lock pick set.text: You skillfully used the lock pick set to quietly unlock the holding cell where Sherlock Smythe was detained, all while maintaining the guise of searching for clues nearby. Your swift actions allowed him to slip out unnoticed and rejoin the ball, his reputation as a brilliant detective intact.

Magnifying glass.text: In an attempt to distract the overzealous security officer, you used your magnifying glass to reflect light into his eyes. Unfortunately, the simplistic ploy was seen through immediately, and the officer simply snatched the magnifying glass from your hand, admonishing you for "childish tricks."

Pocket mirror.text: In an attempt to signal for help, you used the pocket mirror to catch the light and flash a silent alarm to someone outside the ball. Unfortunately, the reflected light only caught the attention of more security, worsening Sherlock's situation without offering a hint of useful communication.

Map.text: In an attempt to use the map to fabricate an alibi for Sherlock by pinpointing his location away from the scene at the time of the accusation, you accidentally highlight his proximity to a separate, unrelated crime, further complicating his situation.

Voice recorder.text: You discreetly recorded Sherlock Smythe's ridiculous theories throughout the evening. When he was arrested, you played the recordings for the chief of police, showcasing that Smythe's "confession" was just a series of absurd, yet harmless, ramblings, leading to his release.

Disguise kit.text: You adeptly apply the contents of the disguise kit to transform an eager, yet befuddled, banquet server into the spitting image of Sherlock Smythe, complete with a fake nose and an impeccable British accent honed from watching too many period dramas. As you wheel out the "arrested" Sherlock (now the server) on a room service cart under the guise of transferring him to a police vehicle, the real Sherlock slips away in the resulting confusion, his reputation as undeservedly untarnished as ever.

Flashlight.text: In an attempt to create a diversion, you flashed the beam directly into the eyes of the arresting officer, hoping to temporarily blind him and snatch the keys. Unfortunately, the officer was wearing anti-glare glasses and promptly charged you with obstruction of justice as well.

Smartphone.text: You discreetly use your smartphone to record a statement from the key witnesses, proving Sherlock's "confession" was nothing more than his usual eccentric speculation. Then, you email the audio files directly to the senior detective on duty, who realizes the mistake and releases Sherlock.

Binoculars.text: You tried to use the binoculars to spy on the real culprit from a safe distance during Sherlock's incarceration. However, all you accomplished was drawing unnecessary attention to yourself, causing the officer to grow suspicious of your seemingly odd behavior at a crime scene.

Decoy flyer.text: You swiftly create a flyer advertising a fake event, "Sherlock Smythe's Masterclass in Deduction", scheduled at the same time as the interrogation. You convince the overzealous security officer that the arrest would lead to public uproar and bad press for the police, urging them to release Sherlock to avoid disrupting the "highly anticipated" event. They reluctantly agree, seeing the potential PR disaster.

Dog treat.text: In an attempt to create a diversion, you throw the dog treat towards a nearby police dog, hoping it'd cause a commotion. Unfortunately, the dog is well-trained and ignores the treat, leaving your plan to free Sherlock unfulfilled.

Art supplies.text: Attempting to fabricate evidence with the art supplies, you clumsily smeared paint over the key documents, making Sherlock's situation even more suspicious in the eyes of the law.

Screwdriver.text: In an ambitious attempt to free Sherlock, you tried to unscrew the hinges of the cell door. However, the screws were tamper-resistant and your standard screwdriver simply stripped the screw heads, making them immovable.

Digital camera.text: You quickly snap a series of photos showing Sherlock Smythe in discussions with other partygoers, carefully timing them to include the clock and other contextual clues proving his whereabouts and conversations at key times, disproving the security officer's misunderstanding without exposing Smythe's ineptitude.

Birdseed.text: Attempting to create a distraction, you scatter the birdseed hoping to attract nearby pigeons to cause chaos and free Sherlock. Unfortunately, no birds are interested in the seed during the night of a bustling ball, leaving your distraction attempt unnoticed and the birdseed wasted on the ground.

Mirror.text: Attempting to use the mirror to distract the security officer, you inadvertently reflected sunlight into Sherlock's eyes, causing him to blurt out another nonsensical confession that further confirmed the officer's suspicions.

Pencil.text: In a frantic attempt to draft a convincing plea for Sherlock Smythe's release, you realize the pencil's lead is broken, and no sharpener can be found in the chaos of the ball.

Translation app.text: In a desperate bid to communicate the misunderstanding to the arresting officer, you use the translation app to bridge the language barrier. Unfortunately, the app mistranslates Sherlock Smythe's convoluted theories into an even more incriminating confession, solidifying the officer's resolve to detain him.

Laptop.text: You quickly set up a live stream from the ball, showcasing Sherlock Smythe's "accidental confession" to the world. Your expert commentary, filled with technical jargon and fabricated psychological analysis, convinces viewers and the authorities that Smythe was employing a novel method of suspect interrogation, not confessing. The security officer, embarrassed but convinced, releases Smythe, who remains oblivious to the close call.

Blanket.text: In an attempt to use the blanket as a makeshift disguise for Sherlock Smythe, you clumsily wrapped it around him, but only succeeded in causing him to trip and fall into the arresting officer, further cementing the officer's suspicion of his guilt.

Headphones.text: You attempted to use the headphones to eavesdrop on the security team, hoping to learn how to invalidate the arrest warrant. Unfortunately, the only thing you picked up was a local radio station's marathon of detective radio dramas, none of which offered any feasible legal advice.

Fishing net.text: You tried to use the fishing net to create a makeshift disguise for Sherlock Smythe, hoping the security would release him if they thought they had caught the wrong man. Unfortunately, the net was too transparent, and the ruse was immediately seen through, leading to an even tighter security watch on Sherlock.

Evidence bag.text: You calmly approached the security officer, presenting the evidence bag as if it held crucial proof of Sherlock’s innocence. Inside, you placed a convincingly doctored piece of evidence that misdirected suspicion away from Sherlock, leading to his release on a technicality.

Tongs.text: Hoping to use the tongs to skillfully snag the key off the overzealous security officer's belt, you instead accidentally pinch his backside. This not only fails to retrieve the key but also earns Sherlock a stern warning about his "associate's" behavior.

Waterproof bag.text: In an attempt to sneak Sherlock out of detention under the guise of retrieving "critical evidence" stored within the waterproof bag, the officer insisted on inspecting its contents first, only to find it peculiarly empty, further arousing his suspicion towards both of you.

Gloves.text: When you tried to use the gloves to suggest that Sherlock was preparing for an experiment that required cleanliness, thus explaining his odd behavior and statements, the overzealous security officer mistook them for incriminating evidence, believing they were meant to avoid leaving fingerprints at a crime scene.

Camera.text: You discreetly recorded the entire conversation between Sherlock Smythe and the overzealous security officer, capturing not only the absurd theories proposed by Smythe but also the lack of any genuine confession. Presenting this evidence to the head of security, you managed to demonstrate that Smythe's ramblings could not be reasonably interpreted as a confession, leading to his immediate release.

Pen.text: In an attempt to craft a fake release order, your pen ran out of ink halfway through the signature, making the document look suspicious and hastily fabricated.

First-aid kit.text: Attempting to create a diversion, you tear open the first-aid kit, spilling its contents all over the floor in front of the arresting officer, hoping to claim an urgent medical emergency. Unfortunately, the officer barely glances at the mess, deciding it's neither suspicious nor urgent, and continues to escort Sherlock Smythe away.

Distraction device.text: During the ball, you secretly activated the distraction device, a small, concealable gadget that emits a loud siren noise and flashing lights. As the guests and security became enveloped in momentary chaos, you calmly explained to the perplexed officer that Sherlock was merely “demonstrating” how a criminal might confess, thus securing his release under the guise of a misunderstanding.

Handkerchief.text: In your attempt to use the handkerchief to craft a makeshift sling, implying Sherlock was injured and needed to be released for medical attention, the security officer merely scoffed, pointing out the complete lack of any visible injury on Sherlock.

Candy.text: In an attempt to lure the thief away from the lifeboat with a trail of candy, you only succeed in attracting the attention of a flock of seagulls, causing chaos on deck and alerting the thief to your interference, allowing them to hasten their escape into the night.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: You thought you could use the noise-cancelling headphones to block out the sounds of Smythe's misguided deductions, focusing solely on the thief. However, this only resulted in you missing crucial audible clues from the thief's movements, letting him slip away unnoticed into the night.

Fake mustache.text: Attempting to disguise yourself with the fake mustache to blend in and not alarm the guests, you quickly realize the mustache is far too comedic and disproportionate for your face. Instead of blending in, you attract odd looks and snickers, making it impossible to approach the thief unnoticed.

Notebook.text: In an attempt to record a discreet clue that would lead Sherlock Smythe in the right direction, you scribbled down the thief's peculiar gait and a partial view of their tattoo. Unfortunately, Smythe, in a rare moment of paying attention, snatched the notebook from you, exclaiming about a "vital clue" he believed he saw in your doodle of the ship's buffet from earlier in the day. This sent him on a wild goose chase through the kitchen, giving the thief ample time to vanish.

Sticky notes.text: In a hasty attempt to mark the thief discreetly with sticky notes so you could track them in the dark, your plan quickly unraveled. The thief, feeling the light touch, simply brushed them off, leaving your sticky notes fluttering into the ocean breeze, useless and ignored.

Costume.text: You quickly donned the costume of a ship's officer, blending in with the crew. With authority now visually vested in you, you convincingly redirected the real officers to intercept the thief, while keeping Sherlock's attention on a decoy pursuit, ensuring the diamond never made it into the lifeboat.

Invisible ink pen.text: In an attempt to leave a trail from the thief to where you could discreetly alert the authorities without Smythe's knowledge, you wrote quick, invisible notes along the way. However, under the dim moonlight, your movements caught the attention of the thief, who, mistaking your actions for those of another competitor, accelerated their escape, disappearing into the night before you could enact your plan.

Lollipop.text: In an attempt to perform a distraction, you unwrapped the lollipop, planning to throw it as a decoy. However, your throw was poorly timed and the sticky confection landed inconspicuously in the sand, ignored by both the thief and Sherlock Smythe, leaving the real situation unresolved.

Tape.text: In an attempt to use the tape to stealthily seal the lifeboat to the ship, preventing its launch, you underestimated the durability of both the tape and the sea's influence. The adhesive gave way under the strain, the thief unbothered and your efforts wasted on the waterlogged roll.

Lock pick set.text: Using your lock pick set, you discreetly unlock a nearby storage closet, quickly ushering the real thief inside and locking them away before anyone, especially Sherlock Smythe, could notice. This covert move ensures the thief's capture without Smythe realizing the true sequence of events.

Magnifying glass.text: In your attempt to use the magnifying glass to analyze the thief's footprints in the dark, you only succeeded in drawing attention to yourself, illuminating your position to the thief and inadvertently alerting them to your presence. The thief quickly changed course and vanished into the shadows, all while Sherlock Smythe remained none the wiser about your blunder.

Pocket mirror.text: In an attempt to use the pocket mirror to signal a nearby security guard silently, you instead catch the moonlight just as Sherlock Smythe glances over, leading him to believe it's a clue from the thief and sending him on a wild goose chase directly away from both the thief and the guard.

Map.text: In a frantic effort, you unfurl the map under the moonlight, hoping to predict the thief's escape route. However, your concentration on the map allows the thief to spot you, mistaking your intent. Panicking, the thief changes course and unknowingly runs straight into a dead-end, getting caught by the security you never intended to alert.

Voice recorder.text: In an attempt to use the voice recorder to mimic the ship's captain and order the thief to halt, you accidentally recorded Smythe's off-key humming from earlier. When played, it not only failed to stop the thief but also alerted Smythe to your location, leading to a comical chase around the deck that ended with nothing but embarrassment.

Disguise kit.text: Using the disguise kit, you quickly don a waiter's uniform and blend in with the ship's staff. Then, you approach the thief under the guise of offering assistance, subtly convincing them to head back inside for a "private celebratory drink," where you quietly alert the real authorities.

Flashlight.text: You used the flashlight to mimic the flashing signals of the coast guard, directing the thief back towards the ship's security team lying in wait, without Sherlock Smythe or the other guests becoming any wiser to the real hero of the night.

Smartphone.text: You use the flashlight app on your smartphone to blind the thief momentarily while you text local authorities with the other hand, providing a precise location and description. The thief is apprehended by the police as they attempt to row away, all without Sherlock Smythe or the guests being any wiser.

Binoculars.text: Using the binoculars, you zoom in on the thief from a distance, identifying them clearly in the moonlight. You then use this information to send an anonymous tip to the ship's security, pointing them in the right direction without Smythe or the guests noticing your interference, ensuring the diamond is recovered and Smythe gets the credit for a job he didn't solve.

Decoy flyer.text: You quickly crafted an announcement about a rare, spontaneous event visible only from the ship's deck, directing attention away from the thief and giving you the chance to catch them quietly. Smythe, along with the passengers, was too enthralled by the prospect of witnessing this faux phenomenon, allowing you to retrieve the diamond without his interference.

Dog treat.text: Attempting to lure the guard dog away from the scene with the treat, you underestimated its discipline. The dog ignores the treat, staying resolutely by its post.

Art supplies.text: In your attempt to create a diversion by hastily sketching a counterfeit diamond and tossing it in the opposite direction, the shadowy figure easily spotted the fake in the dim light, undeterred in their escape attempt, while Smythe ambled towards your poorly crafted distraction, utterly confused.

Screwdriver.text: In an attempt to subtly disable the lifeboat by unscrewing key components, you clumsily dropped the screwdriver into the ocean, alerting the thief and Sherlock Smythe to your presence without hindering the thief's escape.

Digital camera.text: You capture a clear photo of the thief's face and discreetly show it to the security team, who apprehend the culprit without alerting Sherlock Smythe or drawing attention from the guests.

Birdseed.text: In an attempt to lure the shadowy figure away from their escape route, you scatter the birdseed on the deck, hoping the rustling sound will mimic steps. However, it merely attracts a flock of seagulls, waking Sherlock Smythe and several guests with their cacophonous squawking, while the thief slips away unnoticed.

Mirror.text: In an attempt to use the mirror to reflect moonlight, catching the thief's attention and scaring them off, you instead catch Sherlock Smythe's eye. He excitedly rushes towards what he believes is a clue, crashing into you and sending the mirror clattering down the ship's side, shattering on the deck below.

Pencil.text: Attempting to use the pencil as a makeshift tool to pick the lock and access the lifeboat controls, you fumble, and the pencil snaps in half under the strain. Sherlock Smythe, none the wiser, continues barking up the wrong tree, leaving you with nothing but the pieces of your failed attempt.

Translation app.text: In a hurried attempt to communicate with the ship's crew to intercept the thief, the translation app garbled your message into an incomprehensible mix of languages, causing confusion and delaying the response long enough for the thief to vanish into the night.

Laptop.text: In your attempt to use the laptop to hack into the ship's security system and track the thief, you quickly realize there is no Wi-Fi signal available on the open deck, rendering your laptop useless in the crucial moment.

Blanket.text: In an attempt to quietly subdue the thief with the blanket, you instead accidentally draped it over a nearby, ornate lamp, knocking it over. The loud crash alerted both the thief and Sherlock Smythe, drawing unwanted attention to your interference and causing further confusion.

Headphones.text: In an attempt to use the headphones to eavesdrop on the thief's plans from a distance, the rustling of your movements betrays your position, leading the thief to panic, drop the diamond into the ocean, and escape uncaught.

Fishing net.text: In your haste to capture the thief, you cast the fishing net towards the shadowy figure, only to realize too late that the dock's slippery surface isn't conducive to precision throwing. The net lands in a tangled heap far from your target, alerting both Smythe and the thief to your presence.

Evidence bag.text: You planned to use the evidence bag to discreetly capture the diamond from the thief, but in the darkness, you accidentally rustled the bag, alerting the thief to your presence and causing them to hasten their escape.

Tongs.text: In trying to discreetly use the tongs to snatch the diamond from the thief in the dark, you accidentally clinked them together, alerting the thief to your presence and causing him to sprint away with the diamond faster.

Waterproof bag.text: You quickly scoop the diamond from the thief's grasp using the waterproof bag, then throw the bag overboard, pretending to lose the diamond to the sea, all while keeping it secure and dry inside the bag. Later, you "discover" the bag washed ashore with the "recovered" diamond inside.

Gloves.text: As you attempt to discreetly use your gloves to grasp the thief's slippery lifeboat rope, the gloves, designed more for elegance than grip, cause your hands to slide off, sending a loud splash into the silent night, alerting both the thief and Sherlock Smythe to your unintended interference.

Camera.text: You quickly snapped a high-resolution photo of the thief with the diamond in hand, even capturing the unique tattoo on his arm, which later became crucial in identifying him to the authorities. Sherlock Smythe, none the wiser, hailed it as his own genius discovery when you "accidentally" left the photo amongst his case notes.

Pen.text: In your attempt to write a note to the captain about the real thief, you accidentally dropped your pen overboard in the commotion caused by Smythe's antics, leaving you without any means to discreetly communicate the thief's identity.

First-aid kit.text: In an attempt to create a diversion and lure the thief back, you futilely scatter the bandages and antiseptic from the first-aid kit across the deck, hoping to fabricate an urgent medical emergency. The thief, seeing through the ruse, swiftly bypasses the mess, leaving you scrambling to collect the scattered supplies as they disappear into the night.

Distraction device.text: You activate the distraction device, a compact audio player that emits a series of loud, confusing noises, near Sherlock Smythe. The cacophony captures his attention, and he dashes off in the wrong direction, allowing you to quickly intervene and tackle the thief, recovering the diamond in the scuffle.

Handkerchief.text: In an attempt to discretely signal another nearby guest to call for help, you waved your handkerchief vigorously from the shadows. Instead, the action caught the attention of the thief, who, spotting your desperate signaling, panicked and accelerated their escape, disappearing into the ocean’s vastness with the diamond still in their grasp.

Candy.text: In an attempt to create a spectral shape, you scatter candy in the air, hoping the guards and Smythe will mistake it for paranormal activity. Instead, Smythe, ever the sweets enthusiast, immediately recognizes the candy flavors by scent, derailing the ghostly gambit and leaving you scrambling for a new plan.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: In an attempt to use the noise-cancelling headphones to block out the ambient noise and concentrate on creating the "ghostly" sounds, you realized too late that this also made you oblivious to Sherlock Smythe's loud declarations of having seen the ghost—his own shadow, leading to a night of wild ghost chase that served no purpose.

Fake mustache.text: You applied the fake mustache to your face, transforming yourself into the "ghost" of a disgraced Tower guard. As you moaned and clanked chains, Smythe and the guards were so entranced by your spectral performance, they didn't notice you subtly pointing them towards false clues, giving you ample time to uncover the real thief.

Notebook.text: While attempting to sketch a convincing "ghost" in your notebook to use as a prop, Sherlock Smythe peered over your shoulder and loudly declared it a masterpiece of "modern art," utterly missing the point and alerting the guards to your location.

Sticky notes.text: In an attempt to create ghostly figures on the walls of the Tower with sticky notes, you quickly realized that the dim lighting made them nearly invisible, rendering your spectral diversion utterly ineffective.

Your ghostly performance captivated both Sherlock Smythe and the guards, their attention firmly on you, providing the perfect distraction for you to sleuth out the real thief under the guise of your spectral misdirection.

Invisible ink pen.text: In your attempt to manufacture ghostly messages with the invisible ink pen, the heavy fog of London's night rendered the ink undetectable not only under normal light but also under the ultraviolet flashlight you prepared. Without a visible message, the distraction failed, and Sherlock Smythe's focus on ghostly culprits intensified.

Lollipop.text: In trying to simulate ghostly apparitions with the reflective surface of the lollipop, you inadvertently caught the attention of a ravenous raccoon, who, intrigued by the sweet scent, snatched it right from your hands before you could execute your plan.

Tape.text: In an attempt to create a ghostly silhouette, you stretched the tape across a doorway and shined a flashlight on it, hoping it would reflect eerily. Pocket mirror.text: In an attempt to project a spectral image with your pocket mirror, the moonlight you tried to catch only succeeded in momentarily blinding Sherlock Smythe, causing more confusion than misdirection.

Map.text: In an attempt to use the map to create a path that would lead Sherlock Smythe on a wild goose chase, he misinterpreted it and led both of you directly to the guards' break room, interrupting their tea time and raising suspicion rather than averting it.

Decoy flyer.text: You quickly print off a decoy flyer claiming a scheduled spectral performance by the "Tower Ghost" at midnight. Handing them out to Smythe and the guards keeps them glued to the designated spot, giving you the perfect cover to trace the real thief's steps without interruption.

Art supplies.text: In your haste to craft a believable specter from the art supplies, you used too much glitter on the "ghost," leading to Sherlock Smythe, rather than being distracted, becoming utterly fascinated with what he declared was "spectral evidence."

Screwdriver.text: Attempting to dismantle a smoke detector to create a makeshift "ghost" with the screwdriver, you accidentally set off the alarms, drawing more attention instead of creating a distraction.

Mirror.text: As you angled the mirror to create a spectral illusion, Sherlock Smythe, ever eager to face the "ghost" head-on, charged straight into the reflection and shattered the mirror in the process.

Translation app.text: When you attempted to use the translation app to create a ghostly message that would distract both Smythe and the guards, you realized it only translates between known languages, not into "ghostly moans" or any spectral tongues, making it utterly ineffective for generating believable ghostly distractions.

Distraction device.text: You deployed the distraction device, a compact, sophisticated gadget capable of producing eerie sounds and cold gusts, simulating a ghostly presence. Recorder.text: You record eerie noises and ghostly whispers on the recorder, then play them back to echo through the Tower of London's halls. While Smythe and the guards chase the source of these spectral sounds, you uncover the real thief's tracks.

Portable projector.text: Using your portable projector, you cast a convincing spectral image onto the mist enveloping the Tower of London. Smoke bombs.text: You deftly threw smoke bombs at strategic locations around the perimeter of the Tower of London. The emerging mist and shadows, under the moonlit sky, convinced Sherlock Smythe and the guards that they were indeed witnessing a spectral phenomenon, thereby diverting their attention and allowing you discreet access to the scene of the real crime.

Laser pointer.text: Using the laser pointer, you cast dancing lights along the ancient walls, mimicking ghostly movements. Magnet.text: In your attempt to use the magnet to simulate supernatural activity, Sherlock Smythe, in his bumbling manner, mistook the magnetic pull for the ghost's "presence" and decided to communicate with the "spirit" by attaching notes to the magnet, rendering it visible and ineffective as a tool for misdirection.

Light sensor.text: As you set up the light sensor in an attempt to project the optimal illusion of a ghost, Sherlock Smythe, oblivious to its purpose, trips over it in the dark, cracking the delicate electronics beyond repair.

Book.text: Attempting to convince Sherlock Smythe that the book contained ancient rituals to summon a ghost, he opened it eagerly, only to find it was a mundane detective manual, prompting his bewilderment and your mortification.

Chessboard.text: You attempted to arrange the chessboard in a pattern that might suggest supernatural involvement, perhaps to simulate the strategic moves of a ghostly presence. However, Sherlock Smythe, in his bumbling manner, tripped over the chessboard, scattering the pieces and utterly destroying your planned "spectral" pattern before it could even catch a guard's eye.

Crowbar.text: In the eerie silence, attempting to use the crowbar to simulate ghostly sounds only resulted in a cacophony of clumsy clangs, instantly alerting Smythe and the guards to your position rather than creating a diversion.

Candy.text: Attempting to use the candy to trigger the ancient traps safely, you find that the mechanisms are too large and complex for such small, lightweight objects to activate them, causing a misjudgment that alerts the traps to your presence without disarming them.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: As you don the noise-cancelling headphones to avoid the distraction of the ancient traps' cacophony, Sherlock accidentally activates a trap. Unable to hear his cries for help, you can't prevent him from blundering into a pitfall, thus not only failing to safeguard his reputation but further entrenching his incompetence in the eyes of the constabulary.

Fake mustache.text: You place the fake mustache on Sherlock, hoping it would disguise him enough to prevent the activation of a facial recognition trap. Unfortunately, the ancient trap was triggered by weight, not facial features, sending you both toppling into a pit.

Notebook.text: Despite your in-depth notes on historical engineering, the dimly lit passage caused you to misread a crucial detail about disarming a pressure plate, leading to an unexpected release of ancient arrows that barely missed you.

Sticky notes.text: In a bid to mark a safe path through the maze of ancient traps, you hastily place sticky notes on the mechanisms you've deemed harmless. Unfortunately, the dim, musty air of the hidden passage quickly renders the adhesive ineffective; your markers fall away, leading Sherlock Smythe straight into triggering a previously avoided trap, sending both of you tumbling into a net.

Costume.text: As you attempted to bypass a pressure-sensitive floor trap by disguising yourselves as part of the cleaning crew to blend in with the surroundings, your plan unravelled quickly when the ancient mechanism detected the extra weight, not fooled by appearances, sending darts flying your direction. Sherlock Smythe's dramatic flair for the "disguise" tore the costume upon snagging it on a hidden protrusion, rendering it unusable for future escapades.

Invisible ink pen.text: In an attempt to carefully map out the secret passage and its traps with your invisible ink pen, for later revelation under a black light, you underestimated the complexity and ancient mechanisms. Tape.text: Using the tape, you meticulously mark safe paths on the floor, sidestepping ancient pressure plates that would trigger the deadly traps, guiding both yourself and the clueless Sherlock Smythe safely through the perilous passage, all while he takes the credit.

Lock pick set.text: Using your lock pick set, you expertly disarm the ancient traps by manipulating the old lock mechanisms that control them, allowing you and Sherlock to pass safely and undetected.

Magnifying glass.text: Using the magnifying glass, you carefully examined the ancient mechanisms, discerning the wear patterns on the stone caused by the secret passageway's frequent use, thereby identifying safe steps that bypassed the traps without triggering them.

Pocket mirror.text: Attempting to use the pocket mirror to reflect light and disable the ancient traps, you inadvertently signal Sherlock, who, thinking it a clue, blunders into the path of a swinging pendulum trap, barely escaping with his coattails shorter by an inch.

Map.text: Consulting the map, you quickly identify the layout of the secret passage and navigate past the ancient traps, avoiding pitfalls that would have ensnared less prepared explorers. Voice recorder.text: In a moment of inspiration, you used the voice recorder to document the exact sequence of noises each trap made when triggered, hoping to use it as a guide to safely navigate the passage. Disguise kit.text: Using the disguise kit, you carefully apply aged makeup, convincing the keeper of the ancient passage that you are a descendant of the original architects, thereby gaining insider information on how to safely navigate the traps without triggering them.

Flashlight.text: Using the flashlight, you lit up the ancient mechanisms, revealing both their ingeniously simple engineering and their fatal flaws. Smartphone.text: You used your smartphone to illuminate the dark passage, allowing you to safely navigate and disarm the traps using tutorials you found online about ancient engineering techniques.

Binoculars.text: As you peer through the binoculars to closely examine the mechanism of a distant trap, you fail to notice a pressure plate directly beneath your feet. The plate triggers, sending you and Sherlock Smythe tumbling into a pit, further away from the Crown Jewels and the truth.

Decoy flyer.text: In an attempt to divert the ancient traps, you placed the decoy flyer hoping it would trigger and thus reveal the mechanics of the traps. Dog treat.text: In an attempt to distract what you hoped was a pharaoh's curse-bound guardian beast with the dog treat, you instead unearthed an additional layer of mechanical traps, as the ancient mechanisms were unimpressed by modern canine snacks.

Digital camera.text: In an attempt to document the mechanisms of the ancient traps, the flash from your digital camera triggered a light-sensitive trap, sealing the secret passage permanently.

Birdseed.text: In an attempt to distract ancient booby-trapped mechanical guards, you scatter birdseed, hoping to attract nearby birds.
