Magnet.text: As you attempt to disable an ancient crossbow trap with your magnet, hoping to disarm any metal components, you inadvertently trigger the trap instead. The magnet, being too weak to manipulate the mechanism from a safe distance, pulls a small, metal pin too early, releasing a volley of arrows that narrowly miss you and Sherlock Smythe.

Light sensor.text: Using the light sensor, you meticulously detected the presence of hidden beams, pinpointing the exact locations to avoid triggering the ancient traps, thereby navigating safely through the passage with the stolen Crown Jewels clues in hand, all while Sherlock Smythe obliviously marveled at the "mysterious" absence of dangers.

Book.text: In an attempt to use the book on historical engineering to deactivate the traps, you misinterpret a key diagram, causing the floor to give way beneath you, sending the book plummeting into a pit along with several ancient and irreplaceable artifacts.

Rope.text: You quickly fashioned the rope into a series of makeshift pulleys around the ancient traps, cleverly redistributing their weight. This allowed Sherlock Smythe to blunder safely across, blissfully unaware, while you maintained an air of casual guidance.

Chessboard.text: In an ill-conceived attempt to use the chessboard as a map, matching traps to chess pieces' moves, you miscalculate a bishop's diagonal strike. The floor gives way, swallowing the chessboard into oblivion.

Crowbar.text: You use the crowbar to meticulously apply leverage at specific points along the ancient traps' mechanisms, disarming them safely while preserving the structural integrity of the secret passage. This allows you and Sherlock to proceed without triggering any traps, keeping both the truth about the Crown Jewels and Sherlock's reputation intact.

Ghost Simulator.text: Trying to use your Ghost Simulator to scare Sherlock into avoiding the traps only highlighted his obliviousness, as he marched straight into them, convinced they were illusions part of the "haunted" atmosphere, leaving both of you ensnared in a net trap.

Candy.text: Thinking quickly, you attempted to mold the candy into a makeshift voice changer, hoping to mimic Cromwell's exact pitch and timbre. However, when you pressed the candy contraption to your throat and spoke, the only sound that echoed through the chamber was a sticky, muffled mess, far from the authoritative tone needed to unlock the door.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: As Sherlock Smythe bellowed guesses of Cromwell’s voice, you donned the noise-cancelling headphones hoping to analyze and isolate the correct frequency from recordings of Cromwell’s voice imitators. Unfortunately, the headphones only served to drown out Smythe’s incessant, incorrect shouts, offering no aid in actually replicating or analyzing Cromwell's unique timbre and accent, thus leaving the technology-sealed room impenetrably shut.

Fake mustache.text: As you attempt to mimic Cromwell’s voice with only the confidence a fake mustache can bestow, the advanced technology remains unimpressed by your facial hair, leaving the door firmly sealed.

Notebook.text: You attempted to use the notebook to take meticulous notes on Cromwell's voice, hoping to mimic or reproduce it somehow. However, simply jotting down observations on timbre and accent couldn't trick the advanced technology into recognizing your voice as Cromwell's.

Sticky notes.text: Hoping to label the technology's interface for a simpler manipulation, you enthusiastically cover it with sticky notes, each marking a supposed command or trick you might use to mimic Cromwell's voice. Yet, the only outcome is an unamused, silent door and a severe jamming of its sophisticated mechanisms, rendering it utterly inoperable.

Costume.text: Donning a highly detailed costume, you attempt to mimic Cromwell's voice; however, the advanced technology is not fooled by mere appearance and rejects your vocal attempt with an indifferent beep, maintaining its seal on the room.

Invisible ink pen.text: You attempted to use the invisible ink pen to jot down notes on replicating Cromwell's voice, hoping to discover a pattern or technique. Unfortunately, the voice-activated lock required an audible solution, not written insights, leaving your efforts fruitless and unnoticed.

Lollipop.text: Believing the lollipop could modulate your voice to match Cromwell's timbre, you attempt to mimic his accent while sucking on the candy. Unfortunately, the lollipop does nothing to alter your voice, leaving the advanced lock unimpressed and sealed tight.

Tape.text: In a moment of inspiration, you attempted to use the tape to mask your voice to mimic Cromwell's accent, hoping the door's sensors would be fooled by your crude emulation. Unfortunately, the technology detected the ruse instantly, failing to recognize the muffled, taped-over voice as anything remotely authentic, leaving you and Sherlock Smythe red-faced and no closer to the jewels.

Lock pick set.text: In a moment of desperation, you attempted to use the lock pick set on the high-tech seal, but the mechanism, being voice-activated, lacked any physical tumblers or locks to manipulate, rendering the set useless in your hands.

Magnifying glass.text: As Sherlock Smythe pompously attempted to magnify his voice, hoping for any possible acoustic trickery, you held the magnifying glass awkwardly between him and the advanced seal. Predictably, it did nothing but focus a beam of sunlight that uncomfortably warmed the side of Sherlock's face, eliciting a muddled complaint about "infernal heating contraptions" rather than unlocking the door.

Pocket mirror.text: Attempting to use the pocket mirror, you mistakenly believed it would somehow capture and replicate Cromwell's voice. Instead, you only caught a glimpse of your worried expression, realizing the device's true purpose is for reflection, not sound reproduction.

Map.text: You unfurl the map, hoping for clues to mimic Cromwell's voice but it only details geography, utterly useless for audio forgery.

Voice recorder.text: You played a recording of Cromwell’s archived speeches near the lock mechanism, analyzing his voice's nuances. By skillfully adjusting the pitch and speed on your voice recorder, you replicated Cromwell's voice, commanding the door to open.

Disguise kit.text: In your attempt to use the disguise kit to mimic Cromwell's voice, you realize too late that makeup and a false beard do nothing to alter your voice to match a centuries-dead general's. Sherlock Smythe’s attempt to speak in Cromwell's voice, with you behind him mimicking mouth movements, only adds to the absurdity rather than solving the problem.

Flashlight.text: In a misguided attempt to use the flashlight to analyze the lock's construction for vulnerabilities, Sherlock Smythe confuses its purpose, shining it directly into his eyes. Temporarily blinded, he trips over, inadvertently setting off a minor alarm. While you manage to escape notice, the flashlight is left behind in the hasty retreat.

Smartphone.text: You used your smartphone to find and play a recording of Cromwell's voice, which you discovered in an obscure online archive, tricking the system into granting access.

Binoculars.text: Peering through the binoculars, you tried to magnify any hidden mechanism around the sealed door, hoping to spot a way to reproduce Cromwell's voice with the available technology. Unfortunately, the technology was not visual, and thus the binoculars offered no insight into solving the voice-activated lock.

Decoy flyer.text: You tried using the decoy flyer to distract Sherlock while you solved the voice puzzle, but alas, it only intrigued him for a moment before he realized the flyer wasn’t related to the case, leaving you no closer to solving the voice lock.

Dog treat.text: In an attempt to use the dog treat for replicating Cromwell's voice, you coached Sherlock Smythe to use it as a lure, hoping a dog's bark might somehow trigger the mechanism. Unfortunately, not only did this not work, but also the only response was a confused stare from an equally confused Smythe, who then proceeded to eat the treat himself in frustration.

Art supplies.text: You tried to craft a rudimentary voice modulator out of the art supplies, but constructing a device capable of replicating Cromwell's voice required electronics, not watercolors and clay.

Screwdriver.text: In an attempt to open the seal using the screwdriver, you underestimated the precise engineering of the locking mechanism. The screwdriver slipped, scratching the ancient technology and leaving the door firmly shut.

Digital camera.text: You tried to use the digital camera to record the ambient sounds of the room, hoping to catch some clue or whisper of Cromwell's voice left by magic or technology. However, you quickly realized that the camera was not equipped to capture sound with the fidelity necessary for the voice-activated lock, let alone the accent and timbre of Cromwell.

Birdseed.text: You scattered the birdseed across the floor, hoping to attract birds whose chirping could be modulated into Cromwell's voice. Alas, the room's technology was not fooled by avian noises, leaving your tactic embarrassingly ineffective.

Mirror.text: You attempted to use the mirror to reflect your own attempt at Cromwell's voice back at the door's voice recognition system, hoping it would somehow amplify or modify the sound to match Cromwell's voice. Unfortunately, the mirror simply reflected your own unsuccessful attempt back at you, proving ineffective in bypassing the advanced technology.

Pencil.text: Attempting to use the pencil to replicate Cromwell's voice, you scribbled notes and practiced pitches, but the room remained sealed, the pencil unable to mimic human vocal cords.

Translation app.text: You used the translation app to analyze and simulate Oliver Cromwell's specific accent and speech patterns from historical recordings, cleverly convincing the advanced security system that you were indeed Cromwell himself.

Laptop.text: You use the laptop to analyze recordings of Oliver Cromwell’s voice from historical documentaries, then synthesize an approximation using voice generation software. By playing this back at the door’s voice recognition system, it opens without suspicion.

Blanket.text: Wrapping the blanket around your body, you attempt to muffle your voice to match Cromwell's. Unfortunately, the blanket merely muffles your own voice without altering its timbre or accent, rendering the effort futile and leaving the technology unimpressed.

Headphones.text: As you played a recording of Cromwell's speeches, hoping the voice recognition system would be fooled, you quickly realized the headphones merely output sound; they couldn't capture your amateur voiceover or manipulate it to match Cromwell's acclaimed timbre and accent. The sealed room remained silent and unyielding to your approach.

Fishing net.text: In an overzealous attempt to capture any residual sound waves of Cromwell that might be lingering, you draped the fishing net over the sealed door, hoping to ensnare some aspect of his voice. Unfortunately, the net did nothing but hang limply, illustrating a profound misunderstanding of both acoustics and temporal physics.

Evidence bag.text: In a moment of wild creativity, you decided to stuff the evidence bag with various objects you thought might, when shaken, mimic Cromwell's voice in both accent and pitch. Unfortunately, not only did the bag fail to produce anything close to a human voice, it split open from the strain, spilling its contents embarrassingly at your feet in front of the sealed room.

Tongs.text: You attempted to use the tongs to simulate the mechanism within the sealed door, hoping to trick it into opening. Unfortunately, the tongs were too crude a tool for such a delicate task, and the mechanism remained unresponsive to your efforts.

Waterproof bag.text: You attempted to record Cromwell's voice from a historical reenactment video on your phone, placing it in the waterproof bag to project it at the door's voice recognition system. Unfortunately, the bag muffled the sound too much, rendering the attempt futile and the door remained steadfastly closed.

Gloves.text: As you slip on the gloves, hoping to use your hands to mimic Cromwell's voice somehow, you quickly realize gloves can't alter your voice, let alone reproduce the specific timbre and accent required by the voice-activated seal. Sherlock Smythe's bemused gaze confirms the gloves were not the magic solution you'd hoped for.

Camera.text: You attempted to record the sound of the lock, hoping to manipulate the recording to match Cromwell's voice. Unfortunately, a camera is designed for capturing images and videos, not for the sophisticated audio manipulation needed to convincingly replicate Cromwell's voice.

Pen.text: In your bid to replicate Cromwell's voice, you attempted to disassemble the pen, hoping its parts could somehow mimic or amplify the required tones. Alas, the pen remained a mere writing instrument, silent and unhelpful in your hands.

First-aid kit.text: In a desperate bid, you tried to use the antiseptic from the first-aid kit to soothe your throat, hoping it might change your voice enough to mimic Cromwell's. Unfortunately, it only resulted in a temporary, painful bout of coughing that did nothing to trick the advanced lock mechanism.

Distraction device.text: You activated the distraction device outside the sealed room, drawing the attention of the guards and allowing you to covertly record one of them, who was known for his exceptional Cromwell impression, using his voice to gain access. The device remained intact after use.

Handkerchief.text: In a desperate attempt to mimic Cromwell's voice, you use the handkerchief to muffle your voice, hoping to alter its pitch and timbre. Unfortunately, the security system is not fooled by the crude disguise, and the door remains resolutely sealed.

Recorder.text: You cleverly used the recorder to capture snippets of Cromwell's speeches from a documentary on ancient cryptography playing at the museum next door. Merging fragments of his voice, you played the patchwork audio in front of the technologically advanced lock, which mistook it for Cromwell's voice and granted you access.

Historical blueprint.text: Utilizing the historical blueprint, you meticulously construct a device akin to a phonograph but modified with specific components detailed in the blueprint to mimic Cromwell's voice. Ingeniously placing it near the room's entrance, it flawlessly reproduces the correct timbre and accent, unlocking the door.

Portable projector.text: You use the portable projector to cast a documentary featuring Oliver Cromwell, carefully positioning it so the voice emanates from your direction. This tricks the voice recognition system into believing Cromwell is present, opening the door.

Voice modulator.text: You expertly manipulated the voice modulator to mimic the exact timbre and accent of Cromwell, ensuring the ancient technology recognized and responded to the voice, swinging the door wide open before Sherlock Smythe could propose another one of his outlandish theories.

Smoke bombs.text: You used the smoke bombs to trigger the building's ancient ventilation system, demonstrating a rudimentary understanding of security systems. This unexpected action caused an echo throughout the chambers, confusing the voice recognition system enough to misinterpret the cacophony as Cromwell's voice, granting you entry.

Laser pointer.text: In an innovative yet misguided attempt, you aimed the laser pointer at the high-tech lock, hoping to trigger some overlooked mechanical vulnerability. Unfortunately, the device remained unimpressed, leaving the door sealed and Sherlock Smythe inches away from concocting a theory about futuristic feline burglars.

Magnet.text: In your attempt to use the magnet to manipulate the locking mechanism, you find it's entirely non-magnetic, rendering your effort fruitless and causing Sherlock to question the "magnetic personality" of Cromwell loudly enough to alert nearby security.

Light sensor.text: In your attempt to use the light sensor to mimic Cromwell's voice, you misunderstood the device's capabilities. The light sensor, detecting only changes in light intensity, failed to capture or reproduce the crucial acoustic properties needed to unlock the door.

Book.text: You tried using the book to learn about Cromwell's speech patterns, but the detailed historical analysis provided no insights into replicating his unique voice timbre and accent for the advanced technology.

Rope.text: Attempting to manipulate the sophisticated voice-activated lock with a rope only resulted in entangling the device's external components without any progress, leading to an awkward explanation to a confused, yet intrigued, Sherlock Smythe about the supposed "ancient rope technique."

Chessboard.text: In a fruitless attempt, you deploy the chessboard as a makeshift soundboard, sliding pieces across in patterns to mimic Cromwell’s voice. Unsurprisingly, the innovative lock remains unimpressed by your pawn’s lament or knight’s bravado.

Crowbar.text: Attempting to pry open the futuristic door with your crowbar, you quickly realized the gapless seal and advanced materials resisted any such primitive effort, leaving you with a tool ill-suited to subtlety or voice forgery.

Ghost Simulator.text: The Ghost Simulator, designed to manifest spectral presences, failed because it could not replicate the specific voice of Cromwell, only the visual appearance of ghosts it was programmed with.

Candy.text: In a moment of what could generously be termed inspiration, you attempt to use the candy to bribe the ancient mechanical guards patrolling the Tower's lockdown mechanism. Unfortunately, their programming does not include a taste for sweets, and your offering is utterly ignored, leaving you no closer to escape.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: In your attempt to use the noise-cancelling headphones to block out the sound of the alarm and think clearly, you realized too late that it also made you unable to hear the subtle mechanical workings of the ancient lock you needed to manipulate, causing critical time to be wasted.

Fake mustache.text: In a stroke of genius, you stick the fake mustache on an ancient armor display, convincing Sherlock Smythe it's a legendary detective ancestor come to rescue him. While he toasts "his ancestor," you use the distraction to discover and reverse the lockdown mechanism, sliding out the door just as the guards turn the corner.

Notebook.text: In a desperate attempt to find an escape route, you flipped through the notebook for any pre-recorded exits or clues but only found Smythe's incoherent doodles and nonsensical notes, which offered no practical help in this urgent situation.

Sticky notes.text: In a panic, you hastily scrawled a makeshift map on the sticky notes to plot an escape route through hidden passages known only to you. However, Sherlock Smythe, attempting to “assist,” stuck them all over his face and body, believing it would “camouflage” him from the security team's prying eyes. Instead of guiding you out, they led you in circles, right into the path of the approaching security.

Costume.text: You quickly dressed Sherlock Smythe in the costume, transforming him into a convincing medieval knight, blending seamlessly with the Tower's theme. You marched him out, feigning a historical reenactment for the baffled security team, who allowed you both to pass without question.

Invisible ink pen.text: In a panic, you use the invisible ink pen to mark a crude map of your escape route on the ancient wall, only to realize the ink is, indeed, invisible, making your efforts completely futile as you squint at the blank stone.

Lollipop.text: Attempting to use the lollipop to bribe the ancient, rusted lock mechanism, you watched in dismay as the sticky treat merely adhered to the metal, adding a colorful but unhelpful decoration. Sherlock, mistaking your action for a clue, continuously licked the lollipop, convinced it was a secret key, until it was reduced to a mere stick.

Tape.text: In a moment of misguided inspiration, you decided to use the tape to capture your fingerprints, hoping to erase any evidence of your presence. However, in the process, you accidentally covered Sherlock Smythe's face with tape while he was examining a clue, causing a commotion that attracted the attention of the security team even quicker.

Lock pick set.text: With precision and calm under pressure, you utilize your lock pick set to disarm the ancient mechanism's lock, exploiting its old and less complex structure to your advantage. Under the guise of assisting Sherlock Smythe in deducing a "secret escape route," you ingeniously maneuver both of you out of confinement mere moments before the security team's arrival.

Magnifying glass.text: In your haste, you attempted to use the magnifying glass to focus the dim torchlight on the ancient lock mechanism, hoping to discern a hidden mechanism. Unfortunately, the meager light through the thick glass only served to highlight the dust swirling in the stale air, offering no insight into the lock's secrets.

Pocket mirror.text: In a moment of inspiration, you attempt to use the pocket mirror to reflect sunlight and signal for help through the narrow window. Unfortunately, the sun is hidden behind thick clouds, rendering the mirror useless in this situation.

Map.text: You quickly unfold the ancient map, revealing hidden passages unknown to the modern security team. Guiding Sherlock Smythe through the shadows, you both slip through a concealed exit just before the team arrives, leaving no trace of your presence or Smythe's mistake.

Voice recorder.text: In a panic, you tried to record Smythe's confession of his ineptitude, hoping to use it as leverage with the security team. However, in the echoey confines of the ancient tower, the recorder only picked up indistinct garbles overshadowed by the sound of the failing mechanical lockdown mechanism, rendering the recording useless and your plan foiled.

Disguise kit.text: Using the disguise kit, you quickly transform yourself and Sherlock Smythe into two dusty, forgettable statues among the Tower's ancient decor. The security team, assuming you're part of the exhibition, walks right past, allowing you both to surreptitiously follow them out once they've unlocked the mechanism to exit.

Flashlight.text: In a panicked effort to locate an escape route, you pointed the flashlight towards the ceiling, revealing a series of intricate, ancient frescoes rather than a hidden exit. Fumbling in the dark, Sherlock Smythe seized the flashlight from you, promptly dropping it on the hard stone floor, shattering it beyond use.

Smartphone.text: You quickly use your smartphone to scan the room, using its light to discover an almost invisible seam in the wall. A quick internet search reveals it's a known issue with ancient buildings converted into modern attractions. Following online instructions carefully, you manage to reset the lockdown mechanism, discreetly leading Sherlock Smythe out just as the security team arrives, none the wiser to your involvement.

Binoculars.text: In a desperate bid for clarity, you pressed the binoculars to your eyes, hoping to spot an overlooked exit. However, the narrow confines and proximity of the ancient walls turned this attempt into a dizzying, disorienting mess, causing Smythe to loudly lament your sudden "spell of vertigo," drawing the attention of the security team much sooner.

Decoy flyer.text: You swiftly penned a faux treasure hunt on the decoy flyer and tossed it where it would be found by the security team, leading them on a wild goose chase far from your actual location. As they scurried off, distracted by the promise of hidden valuables, you and Smythe made your discreet escape through the servants' quarters, unnoticed.

Dog treat.text: You tried to lure the guard dog away from the security team with the dog treat, hoping it would give you and Sherlock a chance to sneak past. Unfortunately, the treat only made the dog more alert, leading the security straight to your hiding spot behind the ancient armour.

Art supplies.text: In a frantic attempt to use the art supplies to craft a convincing facsimile of a historical artifact, hoping to distract the security team, you and Smythe spent precious moments sketching and painting. Sadly, the charade was unveiled almost immediately as the security team entered, owing to the blatantly modern art styles you inadvertently employed.

Screwdriver.text: You used the screwdriver to manually toggle the ancient lock mechanism back to its original state, exploiting your detailed knowledge of medieval engineering, which you acquired during a case involving a counterfeit armor ring.

Digital camera.text: In a misguided attempt to use the digital camera's flash to signal for help through the narrow windows, you accidentally catch Sherlock Smythe in the shot, who, startled by the sudden flash, lurches backward into a suit of armor. The commotion draws the attention of the security team sooner than anticipated.

Birdseed.text: In an attempt to attract birds that might trigger the ancient tower's outside pressure plates (the only conceivable way out now), you scattered birdseed beneath the windows. Sadly, the birds, utterly confused by the mechanics of the plates and rather indifferent to your urgent plight, merely feasted before flying away, leaving you no closer to freedom.

Mirror.text: In an attempt to use the mirror to reflect light and signal for help through the tower's narrow windows, you forgot that the windows were barred and too high up to aim accurately. Your efforts only succeeded in catching Sherlock Smythe's bewildered reflection as he accidentally knocked the mirror out of your hands, shattering it on the stone floor.

Pencil.text: In a moment of inspiration, you tried to use the pencil to map a route through the hidden corridors of the Tower, believing a secret exit was drawn in the ancient blueprints you found earlier. However, Sherlock Smythe, in his usual overenthusiasm, leaned over to see your progress and accidentally snapped the pencil in half with his elbow, leaving you with no way to mark the correct path.

Translation app.text: In a desperate bid to communicate with the ancient control panel, you whip out the translation app hoping for a miracle. Sadly, the app, designed for modern languages, is utterly confounded by the ancient symbols etched into the mechanism, rendering it useless in your escape attempt.

Laptop.text: In your haste, you attempt to hack into the Tower's security system using the laptop, unaware that it's not equipped with the necessary software or the processing power to breach modern security protocols. The battery dies mid-attempt, leaving you in the dark, both literally and figuratively.

Blanket.text: In a moment of inspiration, you throw the blanket over a guard camera, hoping it will obscure its view and allow you to move undetected. Unfortunately, the blanket is too light and falls off almost immediately, alerting the security to your exact location.

Headphones.text: In a desperate bid to use the headphones as a makeshift lock pick, you only manage to snap one of the earbuds off in the keyhole, further securing your confinement and marshaling the imminent arrival of the security team, due to the unusual noise.

Fishing net.text: In a moment of inspiration, you toss the fishing net at what you presume to be the ancient pulley system, envisioning a miraculous entanglement that might reverse the lockdown. Unfortunately, the net merely drapes over a harmless sconce, contributing neither to your escape nor to the preservation of Smythe's dignity.

Evidence bag.text: In a moment of misguided genius, you decided to use the evidence bag to collect dust off ancient artifacts, hoping to track the airflow and find a hidden passage. Unfortunately, Sherlock Smythe mistook this for a clue gathering and, in his excitement, accidentally ripped the bag while trying to "analyze" the dust, leaving you with no way to discreetly collect or use the dust for your intended purpose.

Tongs.text: In a flustered attempt to use the tongs to manipulate the ancient, mechanical levers inside the wall, you accidentally jam the mechanism even further, causing an ominous grinding noise that echoes through the corridors, alerting the security team to your exact location far earlier than expected.

Waterproof bag.text: In your desperation to use the waterproof bag to collect water from the moat to short-circuit the ancient locking mechanism, you forgot that throwing the filled bag over the wall requires more strength than you possess. The bag hits the wall and falls back, soaking both you and Sherlock Smythe, and doesn’t reach the lock mechanism at all.

Gloves.text: In a desperate attempt to avoid detection, you pull on the gloves, planning to smudge the fingerprints left behind on the lockdown mechanism. Unfortunately, the gloves are too slick, causing you to fumble and accidentally press a button that blares an alarm throughout the tower, hastening the security team's arrival.

Camera.text: In a misguided attempt to use the camera's flash to temporarily blind the arriving security team, you instead alert them to your exact location within the vast, echoing confines of the Tower. The flash acts like a beacon, ensuring their swift arrival.

Pen.text: In a moment of inspiration, you attempted to use the pen to create a makeshift lockpick. Unfortunately, your expertise in penmanship did not translate to locksmithing, resulting in a broken pen and no closer to escape.

First-aid kit.text: In a desperate bid, you attempted to use the first-aid kit's scissors to jimmy open an ancient lock, but the scissors were far too flimsy for such a task and broke upon the first attempt, leaving the lock unaffected and you still trapped.

Distraction device.text: You set the distraction device near the entrance and activate it, emitting a series of loud, bizarre noises that mimic the Tower's ancient alarm system. The security team, convinced another part of the Tower is in peril, diverts their course, allowing you to find an overlooked escape route in the ensuing chaos.

Handkerchief.text: Attempting to use the handkerchief to catch the light and signal for help, you quickly realize the heavy stone walls block any view from the outside, rendering your efforts futile.

Recorder.text: In an attempt to mimic the sounds of the ancient mechanism reversing, you played the recorder with all the subtlety of a cat walking on piano keys. The security team wasn't fooled and only hastened their approach, their footsteps echoing down the stone corridor.

Historical blueprint.text: Using the historical blueprint, you quickly identified a forgotten medieval escape tunnel hidden behind a movable stone in the cellar. By cleverly guiding Sherlock Smythe to "discover" this escape route, you were able to exit the Tower unnoticed by the security team.

Portable projector.text: In an attempt to create a diversion, you set up the portable projector to cast the shadow of an imposing figure onto the wall, hoping to scare off the security team. However, the battery dies within seconds, revealing not a terrifying specter but a dim flicker, barely noticeable against the ancient stones, leaving you both in the dark and no closer to escape.

Voice modulator.text: You quickly set the voice modulator to mimic the Chief of Security's voice, and command the approaching security team via the intercom to "abort the search, it was a false alarm." Buying enough time, you lead Sherlock Smythe to a little-known maintenance corridor you've discovered before, making a stealthy escape while the security team disperses.

Smoke bombs.text: You deftly deployed a smoke bomb at the base of the ancient door, confusing the security team long enough for you to discover a hidden mechanism that releases the lock, allowing both of you to slip away unnoticed under the cover of the smoke.

Laser pointer.text: In a desperate attempt to distract the nearing security team, you shone the laser pointer onto a distant wall. However, this only served to make them more alert and hasten their approach, as they mistook the red dot for the beam of a laser sight, concluding that an armed intruder was present.

Magnet.text: In your haste, you thought the magnet could manipulate the ancient iron lockdown mechanism from a distance, but unfortunately, the alloy used was non-magnetic, rendering the magnet ineffective in your escape attempt.

Light sensor.text: In an effort to utilize the light sensor to disarm the lockdown mechanism by mimicking the natural decrease of light at day's end, you find the sensor is too insensitive to the specific light spectrum used by the ancient technology, failing to trigger the desired effect.

Book.text: In an attempt to use the book as a means to trigger a hidden switch or lever, you accidentally drop it on Smythe's foot, causing him to howl in pain and attract the attention of the nearby security team.

Rope.text: You quickly tied one end of the rope to a sturdy, ancient sconce mounted on the wall near a window. Then, you fashioned a loop, dropping it outside to hook onto a protruding stonework, creating an improvised rappelling device. Navigating down the tower's exterior, you ensured Sherlock Smythe followed, albeit clumsily, to the ground below, avoiding the incoming security team.

Chessboard.text: You hoped to use the chessboard to map out a strategy for navigating the tower's corridors, but Sherlock Smythe mistook it for a game, scattering the pieces in a fit of excitement over a match.

Crowbar.text: You deftly use the crowbar to wedge between the ancient doors of the Tower, applying just the right amount of leverage to trigger the release mechanism without damaging the historic artifact. The door creaks open, allowing you and Smythe a discreet exit, moments before the security team rushes in.

Ghost Simulator.text: You activate the Ghost Simulator, expecting to create a convincing spectral distraction. However, Sherlock Smythe, in his infinite wisdom, loudly declares, "Fear not, citizens! It's merely a projected apparition devised by my brilliant assistant!" drawing the immediate attention of the security team to your exact location.

Candy.text: You attempted to distract Sherlock Smythe with a trail of candy, leading him away from the jewels. Unfortunately, Smythe, in his eagerness, stumbled upon the candy too aggressively, causing a loud commotion that alerted the guards before he could even touch a piece.

Noise-cancelling headphones.text: In your haste to avoid Sherlock Smythe's noisy distractions, you donned your noise-cancelling headphones, only to miss the soft, crucial clicks of the pressure-sensitive floor that signaled safe passage, leading to a precarious situation where stepping forward without auditory clues resulted in triggering the bomb alarm.

Fake mustache.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock Smythe, you place the fake mustache on your face, hoping to draw him away from the jewels with a disguise. However, Smythe, ever oblivious to subtlety, fails to notice your new "disguise" and proceeds forward, setting off the alarm when his foot strays onto the pressure-sensitive floor.

Notebook.text: In an attempt to distract Smythe and calculate a safe pathway across the pressure-sensitive floor, you hastily scrawl out a fake set of intricate instructions and diagrams. However, your ruse backfires spectacularly when Smythe, eager to demonstrate his 'expertise', snatches the notebook and, misunderstanding your diagrams entirely, strides confidently forward, setting off the alarm and resulting in an immediate, chaotic evacuation of the premises.

Sticky notes.text: In an attempt to prevent Sherlock from stepping on the pressure-sensitive floor, you hurriedly place sticky notes along a safe path you carefully deduced. However, Sherlock Smythe, in his boundless ignorance, believes these notes to be a bread-crumb trail of clues leading directly to the Crown Jewels. Without hesitation, he steps off the predetermined path to follow them "more closely," triggering the alarm.

Costume.text: You decided to distract Sherlock Smythe by quickly donning the costume and playing the part of an infamous thief, hoping to lure him away from the jewels. Unfortunately, Smythe, in his eagerness to apprehend the "thief", charged forward, tripping over your extended foot, and his flailing almost triggered the bomb, making the situation even more precarious.

Invisible ink pen.text: In an attempt to devise a safe path, you quickly jot down notes on the pressure-sensitive floor with your invisible ink pen, planning to illuminate them with a UV light later. Unfortunately, in the darkness, Sherlock Smythe stumbles directly into your carefully plotted course, setting off the bomb before you have a chance to reveal your inked guide.

Lollipop.text: In your haste to prevent Sherlock Smythe from stumbling into disaster, you unwrapped the lollipop and attempted to use its sticky surface to disarm the pressure-sensitive floor. Unfortunately, the lollipop adhered to your glove instead, rendering your attempt futile as Smythe blundered forward, triggering the alarm.

Tape.text: As you meticulously lay down the tape in an attempt to mark a safe path across the pressure-sensitive floor, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your efforts for some avant-garde ribbon-cutting ceremony, zealously grabs the end of the tape and pulls, triggering the alarm and sealing both your fates.

Lock pick set.text: In an attempt to disable the pressure-sensitive floor, you confidently kneel to pick the lock on the control panel. Unfortunately, your lock pick set is designed for traditional tumbler locks, not the high-tech digital interface securing the bomb mechanism, rendering the attempt futile and your tools irrelevant in this scenario.

Magnifying glass.text: In a misguided attempt to use the magnifying glass to discern the safe path by closely examining the pressure-sensitive floor for wear marks, Smythe, intrigued by your focus, leans in too close, bumping your arm. The magnifying glass slips from your grasp, focusing a beam of moonlight onto a sensor in the process and triggering the bomb before you could even whisper a warning.

Pocket mirror.text: You use the pocket mirror to carefully reflect the moonlight, creating a pathway of light that illuminates the safe stepping stones across the pressure-sensitive floor. This ingenious method allows you to guide Sherlock Smythe by the shoulder, whispering careful directions to ensure he doesn't make a disastrous step, thereby retrieving the Crown Jewels undetected.

Map.text: You quickly unrolled the map, a detailed blueprint of the Tower of London's security systems, including the pressure-sensitive floor's safe paths. Guiding Smythe with precise instructions, you both navigated through the moonlit room, retrieving the Crown Jewels without a hitch or any suspicion towards Smythe's abilities.

Voice recorder.text: You tried to distract Sherlock Smythe by recording a misleading message, hoping he would follow the sound away from the jewels. However, he mistook the recorded message for a real person trapped inside the room, charging forward to the rescue, and triggering the bomb.

Disguise kit.text: In an attempt to use the disguise kit to transform Sherlock into a less conspicuous figure, you accidentally arouse his curiosity about the art of disguise. He insists on trying it himself, which results in a disastrously loud mishap as he knocks over the kit, alerting the guards to your presence before you can even approach the pressure-sensitive floor.

Flashlight.text: Trying to prevent Smythe from moving forward, you flicked on the flashlight to guide him safely. Unfortunately, the sudden light caught Smythe's attention more than the jewels themselves, causing him to charge directly towards you and onto the pressure-sensitive floor.

Smartphone.text: In a desperate attempt to use the smartphone's flashlight feature to navigate the pressure-sensitive floor, you didn't realize that Sherlock Smythe, curious about the sudden light, would clumsily barge in, causing both of you to narrowly escape the triggered explosion. The smartphone flew from your grip and shattered against the stone wall in the chaos.

Binoculars.text: Peering through the binoculars to discern a safe path, you underestimated Sherlock Smythe's fascination with lustrous objects. His abrupt shove to get a closer look at the jewels through the binoculars sent both of you stumbling, activating the pressure-sensitive floor.

Decoy flyer.text: You quickly distract Sherlock Smythe by tossing the decoy flyer, which advertises a fake lecture on the "Art of Deduction by Sherlock Smythe," across the room. His vanity captures his attention, and he rushes to read about the event, giving you the critical moments needed to safely navigate the pressure-sensitive floor and secure the Crown Jewels.

Dog treat.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock Smythe, you toss the dog treat towards a shadowed corner, hoping it will lead him away. Unfortunately, Sherlock, rather than the ever-absent guard dog you hoped to lure, rushes after the treat, stumbling over and triggering the pressure-sensitive floor just before the bomb is set off.

Art supplies.text: In an attempt to safely diagram a path across the pressure-sensitive floor, you hastily sketch a map with the art supplies. However, Smythe, ever eager to "assist," grabs your drawing and, misunderstanding it as modern art, hurls it with delight towards the Crown Jewels, setting off the bomb in a catastrophic display of his lacking acumen.

Screwdriver.text: In an attempt to use the screwdriver to disarm the bomb connected to the pressure-sensitive floor, you slip, pressing too hard and piercing the device's delicate wiring. The bomb's timer accelerates, forcing you to abort the mission prematurely and drag Sherlock Smythe to safety before an embarrassing explosion reveals his incompetence.

Digital camera.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock and guide him safely across the room, you tried to use the digital camera to take flashes of the crown jewels, hoping to simulate lightning bolts as a method of misdirection. Unfortunately, Smythe, ever curious and lacking in subtleness, noticed the camera's flash and, thinking he'd found a clue, barreled forward, setting off the pressure-sensitive floor immediately.

Birdseed.text: In a moment of inspiration, you toss birdseed onto the pressure-sensitive floor, hoping the pigeons that roost in the tower will alight delicately enough to not trigger the bomb. Unfortunately, Sherlock Smythe, in his confused excitement, mistakes the birdseed for clues and stomps right after them, setting off the alarm.

Mirror.text: You quickly discern the path across the pressure-sensitive floor using the mirror to reflect the moonlight, highlighting the safe steps by the absence of dust. Sherlock Smythe, eager to claim credit, bounds forward, but you cleverly redirect him to "inspect" a far corner while you retrieve the jewels.

Pencil.text: In an attempt to mark a safe passage across the pressure-sensitive floor, you press the pencil's tip against the ground, intending to leave a trail. However, the slight pressure from the pencil triggers the floor, setting off the bomb before you can even draw a line.

Translation app.text: As you hurriedly toggle the translation app, attempting to decipher the ancient script warning of the pressure-sensitive floor to Smythe, the bright screen glare inadvertently attracts his attention. He bounds over, exclaiming, "What's this gadget?" and in his excitement, steps onto the pressure-sensitive floor, triggering the bomb.

Laptop.text: In a bid to utilize the laptop to disarm the bomb or guide your steps, you hastily open it, only to find no Wi-Fi signal in the depths of the Tower, rendering your plans useless as Smythe’s impatience grows.

Blanket.text: In an attempt to distribute your weight and avoid triggering the bomb, you carefully spread the blanket across the pressure-sensitive floor, hoping to walk across it. Unfortunately, the blanket is not nearly sturdy enough to diffuse your weight, and the moment you step onto it, you feel the unmistakable click of the mechanism activating beneath your misplaced faith in household textiles.

Headphones.text: You hoped to use the headphones to play an audio recording of a step-by-step guide for navigating the pressure-sensitive floor safely. Unfortunately, when you briefly removed one earphone to ensure Smythe stayed put, his loud declarations of "discovery" caused a feedback loop through the microphone you forgot was active on your device, rendering the recording inaudible amidst screeches.

Fishing net.text: In your attempt to use the fishing net to secure the Crown Jewels without setting foot on the pressure-sensitive floor, you underestimated the weight of the treasures. The moment the fishing net made contact with the crowns, the added strain caused it to tear, groaning under the jewels' weight before it gave way completely, leaving the jewels clattering against the pressure-sensitive floor. The bomb's warning beep begins, heralding your failure.

Evidence bag.text: In an attempt to use the Evidence bag to safely distribute your weight across the pressure-sensitive floor, you underestimated its thin material. The moment it contacted the sharp corner of a gem pedestal, it tore, leaving you scrambling as Sherlock Smythe announced his intentions to fetch the jewels himself.

Tongs.text: You quickly ascertain the only safe approach is from above. Using the tongs with precision, you extend your reach, carefully lifting each jewel off the pressure-sensitive floor without setting off the bomb, while distracting Smythe by asking him to calculate the exact weight of the air in the room, keeping him busy and away from the action.

Waterproof bag.text: In a desperate bid to prevent Sherlock Smythe's approach, you hastily throw the waterproof bag onto the pressure-sensitive floor, hoping to test the path safely. Unfortunately, the bag's weight is insufficient to mimic a human, failing to trigger the mechanism and offering no clue to navigate through the minefield safely. Smythe, undeterred, steps forward recklessly.

Gloves.text: You quickly donned the gloves, allowing you to gently manipulate a nearby toolkit, disarming the pressure-sensitive floor by carefully cutting the wires connected to the bomb, all while Sherlock Smythe stared in awe, oblivious to your expert tinkering.

Camera.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock Smythe, you aimed your camera at the jewels, planning to use the flash. However, the flash simply illuminated the scene, drawing Smythe's attention even more and causing him to stumble directly onto the pressure-sensitive floor.

Pen.text: As you attempt to use the pen to mark a safe path across the pressure-sensitive floor, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your intentions, jovially grabs it to sign what he believes is an autograph for a nonexistent admirer, inadvertently flinging it into a shadowy corner of the room, far from reach.

First-aid kit.text: In a moment of desperation, you opened the first-aid kit, hoping its contents could either disable the pressure-sensitive floor or at least protect Sherlock Smythe from the bomb's effects. Unfortunately, while searching through bandages and antiseptics for something useful, Smythe, curious as ever and fascinated by the assortment of medical supplies, stumbled forwards, setting off the alarm without even getting close to the jewels.

Distraction device.text: You quickly deploy the distraction device, programming it to mimic the sound of the Queen's Guards approaching. Sherlock Smythe, eager to avoid confrontation, ducks into a nearby alcove, allowing you the precious moments needed to carefully navigate the pressure-sensitive floor and retrieve the Crown Jewels.

Handkerchief.text: In an attempt to use the handkerchief to test the pressure sensitivity of the floor, you underestimated the sensitivity, causing the handkerchief to trigger the bomb alarm before Sherlock Smythe could even take a step. The authorities were alerted immediately to the intrusion.

Recorder.text: In an attempt to distract Sherlock Smythe, you played a recording of an apparent police siren, hoping to convince him to wait outside. Unfortunately, the sound only bolstered his excitement, causing him to hurry forward, tripping and activating the pressure-sensitive floor before you could intervene.

Historical blueprint.text: Using the historical blueprint, you quickly identified the non-pressure sensitive stones that made a safe path to the Crown Jewels. You guided Sherlock Smythe step by step, whispering directions and pretending to admire his "brilliant deduction" of the safe route, thus retrieving the jewels without triggering the bomb and maintaining Smythe's farcical reputation.

Portable projector.text: In your haste to distract Sherlock Smythe, you projected a hologram of the Crown Jewels onto the opposite wall. Unfortunately, Smythe, ever the fool, charged at the holographic jewels, tripping into the real pressure-sensitive floor and setting off the alarm before you could stop him.

Voice modulator.text: Despite your best intentions, using the voice modulator to mimic the bomb disarming expert's instructions only confused Sherlock Smythe more, causing him to step carelessly on the pressure-sensitive floor.

Smoke bombs.text: You quickly deployed a smoke bomb, enveloping the room in a thick fog. Utilizing the temporary cover, you cautiously navigated the pressure-sensitive floor and safely secured the Crown Jewels, all while Sherlock Smythe coughed and fumbled around in confusion, nowhere near the precarious ground.

Laser pointer.text: Using the laser pointer, you distracted Sherlock Smythe by shining it against the far wall, much like distracting a cat. This allowed you to carefully navigate the pressure-sensitive floor and retrieve the Crown Jewels, all while Smythe was preoccupied chasing the red dot.

Magnet.text: As you subtly try to use the magnet to manipulate the metal components of the pressure-sensitive floor from a safe distance, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your intentions, eagerly snatches the magnet, believing it to be his magnifying glass. In his confusion, he drops it, sending it skittering across the pressure-sensitive floor, instantly triggering the bomb alarm.

Light sensor.text: You ingeniously set the light sensor to detect the safest path by mapping out the intensity of the shadows cast by the moonlight, ensuring any unweighted areas (and thus, safe to step) were lit up in a sequence. This allowed you to carefully guide Smythe like a puppet, ensuring he only stepped where shadows fell correctly, avoiding any pressure-sensitive triggers.

Book.text: In a desperate attempt to distract Sherlock, you present him with a book on the intricate history of the Crown Jewels, hoping to keep him engrossed. However, Sherlock, in his overexcitement, flings the book aside in his rush towards the jewels, setting off the alarm and sealing both your fates.

Rope.text: You quickly tie one end of the rope around Sherlock Smythe's waist, whispering a quick excuse about ensuring his safety. Then, you expertly toss the other end across the pressure-sensitive floor, latching it onto a sturdy object. Using the rope as a guide, you carefully pull both you and Smythe across the room without touching the floor, averting disaster and securing the jewels.

Chessboard.text: In a flash of inspiration, you laid the chessboard across the pressure-sensitive floor, hoping its grid might map a safe path. Unfortunately, Sherlock Smythe, mistaking your intent for a challenge, eagerly trod upon it, scattering pieces and triggering the alarm before you could stop him.

Crowbar.text: In an attempt to use the crowbar to carefully displace a negligible amount of weight from the pressure-sensitive floor, you underestimated its sensitivity. The moment the metal end grazed the surface, a low hum signaled your failure, followed by Sherlock's oblivious step forward that sealed the deal.

Ghost Simulator.text: Using the Ghost Simulator, you hoped to scare Sherlock Smythe into staying put. Unfortunately, Smythe, more curious than scared, tried to "debunk" the apparition, stumbling directly onto the pressure-sensitive floor.

intro.title: The Unseen Hand of Sherlock Smythe
intro.text: You find yourself in the shadow of the world's most celebrated yet secretly ineffectual detective, Sherlock Smythe. Beyond the facade of brilliance lies your cunning, keeping disaster at bay through wit and sleight of hand. Prepare to navigate a hilariously precarious path of deception, where your smarts preserve the legend and solve the unsolvable.

terrible.name: Shadows and Disgrace
terrible.text: It's a cold, bitter night as you watch Sherlock Smythe, once hailed as a consulting detective extraordinaire, now the laughingstock of the world. Exposed as a charlatan, thanks to one high-profile blunder too many, the truth of his incompetence and your role as the true detective behind the curtain unravels. London whispers your names in pity and scorn. Alone, discredited, and jobless, you wander the shadowy streets, knowing that every unsolved case is a ghost that will haunt you forever. The partnership that once thrived on secrets now lies in ruins, as does your reputation.

bad.name: A Sidelined Specter
bad.text: In the aftermath, you find yourself sidelined, a mere footnote in the scandalous downfall of Sherlock Smythe. While you managed to save him from complete disgrace, the truth about his ineptitude has partially surfaced, casting a shadow over your secret contributions. You're forced to work in the fringes, solving inconsequential mysteries that barely challenge your intellect. Smythe, oblivious to the depths of his fall from grace, continues to bluster through cases, leaving you to clean up the mess in silence. Justice is served, but your role remains unrecognized, the unsung hero in a farce.

middling.name: The Curtained Triumph
middling.text: The world continues to celebrate Sherlock Smythe as a master detective, blissfully unaware of the farce at its heart. You receive a modest salary, enough to live on but hardly reflective of the mental gymnastics required to keep Smythe's reputation afloat. The satisfaction of solving cases underpins your existence, a bitter reminder of the shadows where you must dwell. While justice is often served, the glory is not yours to claim. You remain behind the curtain, forever the architect of Smythe's success yet craving a recognition that never comes.

good.name: The Unsung Guide
good.text: Sherlock Smythe's fame has grown, as has the complexity of the cases laid at his feet - cases you've solved from the shadows. A small circle of insiders knows the truth of your genius, offering clandestine respect and discreet opportunities for true detective work. You enjoy the thrill of the challenge, even if Smythe unknowingly reaps the public adoration. Your guidance ensures justice is served, carving out a unique space where you're content to operate, respected by those in the know, even if Smythe remains cluelessly at the spotlight's center.

great.name: The Ghost Detective
great.text: Your role as the invisible hand guiding Sherlock Smythe to glory has become the stuff of quiet legend. A select few of the city's elite know and appreciate the true mastermind. You're offered cases that require your unique, deft touch, operating in a world of intrigue and shadows. Smythe remains the public figure, but your subtle influence shapes the narrative, steering him away from scandal. You find satisfaction in the knowledge that your intellect and cunning keep the wheels of justice turning, even as Smythe basks in the glory.

perfect.name: The Mastermind's Ascension
perfect.text: Against all odds, you've navigated the treacherous waters of deception and brilliance, guiding Sherlock Smythe through cases with such finesse that not only has his reputation remained intact, yours has risen spectacularly. In a stunning turn of events, the Queen herself summons you. With Smythe bumbling by your side, you receive recognition for your unmatched intellect and bravery. As Smythe stands befuddled, you're knighted. The world knows now: You are the true detective savant. Newspapers hail your genius, universities vie for lectures, and you dine with royalty. Smythe, ever the fool, remains in your shadow, a comfortable place from which you launch into a future bright with promise and acclaim. You've not only solved every case with perfection but have also sculpted a new narrative where the mastermind steps into the light, forever changing the course of detective history.
